results.title: Cracking the stone age code
results.creator_credit: David Collison, Paul Johnstone and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Examines the work of Alexander Thom, former professor of engineering science at Oxford, whose investigations into stone circles and standing circles of Britain threaten to upset prehistoric knowledge. We see him at work in Scotland, and then go to Britain to see how his findings apply there.

results.title: Cholesterol: eat your heart out
results.brief_description: Set in Toronto, this film follows an experiment designed to determine the effect of diet on the blood cholesterol level of high school students. Points out benefits of reducing cholesterol in the diet. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Art of the Persian carpet
results.brief_description: Depicts the entire process of creating Persian carpets, from preparing and dyeing the wool, through the intricate symbolic design patterns, to the complex handwork where young weavers tie up to three million knots to complete one carpet. Shows the remote Indian tribes who weave the finest carpets. Suitable for Upper Secondary students.

results.title: Albert Camus: a self-portrait
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, Fred Orjain and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: An examination of the writing and philosophy of Albert Camus. This documentary traces the genesis of Camus’ existentialism in his relationship to the geography and culture of Algeria. Born of French parents but growing up among Arabs, Camus’ exploration of the agony of human separation reflects his own dichotomous identity. This film also includes a filmed conversation with the writer in which he talks about his love for theatre, football and the importance of achieving personal happiness in a world in which we are condemned to suffer the agonising silence of the unknown Universe. Excerpts from his novels and essays are read throughout the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Georges Rouquier, Fred Orjain and Learning Corporation of America

results.title: Passage
results.creator_credit: Normand Gregoire, Rene Jodoin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film shows the capacity of the camera to suspend or speed up the viewer’s perception of motion. It is a film without words or people, where the screen is alive with light, movement and sound. Fleeting impressions are greatly accelerated as from the windows of a speeding train. The sun rockets through a vortex of clouds, light flickers — all to the shythm of chattering wheels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Normand Gregoire, Rene Jodoin and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Oldest wonder
results.brief_description: This film investigates the development of the pyramid shape for the Egyptian tombs, and how it was possible to build the Great Pyramid within thirty years. The myths surrounding the pyramids are explored and the scientific techniques used to explore them are examined. Narrated by Magnus Magnussen.

results.title: Christopher Columbus
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Gordon Clark, Michael Latham and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers”.
Stresses the most fascinating part of Columbus’s life - the period after he discovered the American continent in 1492. Presented by David Attenborough. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary level.

results.title: Francisco Pizarro
results.creator_credit: Fred Burnley, Michael Latham and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers”.
Depicts the events leading to the destruction of the Inca civilization by Europeans. In the wake of the civil war there was little to stop the invasion of Pizarro and his conquistadores and the Inca civilization fell because of Pizarro’s greed for power and wealth. Written by Ian Thorne and presented by David Attenborough.

results.title: Burke and Wills
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers”.
In 1860 Robert Burke and a party of explorers began the first overland crossing of Australia from Melbourne to the Gulf of Carpentaria. Both Burke and Wills perished on the way back. The film reconstructs the events that led to their deaths. This film is suitable for Years 7-12.
